clinical_study.brief_title: Fenofibrate and Propranolol in Burn Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Mechanisms of Fenofibrate and Propranolol Alone or Combined in Burn Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

collaborator.agency: National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS)

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston

brief_summary.textblock: The proposed study will test the hypothesis that Propranolol, fenofibrate and fenofibrate plus propranolol have therapeutic, physiological, and metabolic effects that will improve clinical outcomes, and the long-term recovery, rehabilitation, and QOL in burned patients.

detailed_description.textblock: Determine the clinical benefits and underlying mechanisms whereby the metabolic perturbators fenofibrate and propranolol impact burn patient outcomes. The investigators hypothesize that these metabolic regulators given for one year will maintain body mass, improve muscle function by increasing protein synthesis, augment wound healing, reduce fibrosis, improve cardiovascular function, reduce systemic inflammation, restore insulin sensitivity, and decrease liver dysfunction without the risk of the hypoglycemia.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization up to one year
primary_outcome.description: Glucose levels and amount of regular insulin infused during hospitalization.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From randomization up to one year
secondary_outcome.description: Resting energy expenditure (REE) done weekly while in hospital

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an average of 5 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Multiply the subjects resting heart rate and systolic blood pressure measurements and average every 24 hours while hospitalized
